thread.title: High Gasoline Prices in California Make Profits for Refiners - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: High Gasoline Prices in California Make Profits for Refiners - Yahoo Finance

author: Manu Milan
title: High Gasoline Prices in California Make Profits for Refiners - Yahoo Finance
text:
ExxonMobil's California Refinery Outage May Prolong the Crack Spread Trend 
( Continued from Prior Part )
Retail gasoline price overview According to the American Automobile Association’s Fuel Gauge Report, after two weeks of holding steady at $2.29 per gallon, the national average price for regular unleaded gasoline began rising last week and reached a price of $2.31 per gallon on October 13, 2015.

California and Los Angeles retail gasoline prices higher than US average According to the EIA (U.S. Energy Information Administration), California and Los Angeles retail prices for regular gasoline averaged $0.96 per gallon and $1.27 per gallon higher than the US average, respectively, in July, and prices averaged $0.76 per gallon and $0.90 per gallon higher than the US average, respectively, in September.
However, California and Los Angeles retail prices are $0.72 per gallon and $0.62 per gallon lower, respectively, than during the same time last year. This reflects a broader fall in crude oil prices.
Why are retail gasoline prices up? The increase in wholesale spot prices has also resulted in higher retail gasoline prices, particularly in Southern California. California retail gasoline prices are typically higher than the US average as a result of higher taxes and differences in gasoline specifications.
ExxonMobil’s impact on gasoline prices in California According the Los Angeles Times , a major contributing factor to the high gasoline prices has been low production at the ExxonMobil (XOM) Torrance refinery, which was damaged in a February explosion.
The plant, which normally accounts for 10% of the state’s capacity and 20% of capacity in Southern California, has operated at less than 20% of normal production since the explosion.
Refiners making profits from high gasoline prices Due to a high crack spread and access to crude oil at lower prices, refiners’ operating costs are quite low. High gasoline prices are boosting refiners’ margins, especially those of companies operating in California such as Phillips 66 (PSX), Tesoro (TSO), ExxonMobil, Valero (VLO), and Chevron (CVX). ExxonMobil and Chevron account for 29.8% of the Energy Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLE).
Browse this series on Market Realist: 
Part 1 - California Gasoline Imports Push Prices Higher Basic Materials Industry Southern California California ExxonMobil gasoline prices
